title: Managing Migraines

content: Migraines affect over 37 million Americans, according to the Migraine Research Foundation (MRF). They can derail your career and reduce your productivity.
Migraine-related pain is the third most prevalent illness in the world. If you have these recurrent, moderate to severe headaches, your pain can be debilitating and last a lifetime.

According to the Global Burden of Disease study, migraines are the second leading cause of disability worldwide. Migraine attacks often involve throbbing pain, nausea, sensitivity to light and sound, and other symptoms that can last extended periods of time often ranging from 4 to 72 hours.
It’s key to keep a list of what may cause your onset of a headache. It’s good to keep a migraine journal to discover your unique triggers.
Identifying and avoiding your migraine triggers is the first step to managing the pain. Of those with migraines, 90% report at least one trigger, according to the American Migraine Foundation (AMF).
bullets: Stress. Over 50% say stress causes their migraines.
Hormonal changes. Fluctuating estrogen is a trigger for 60% of women.
Certain foods like aged cheese, alcohol, and chocolate. Tyramine-rich foods are a known trigger.
Irregular sleep. Too much or too little sleep can trigger attacks.
Dehydration. Even mild dehydration can trigger migraines.
Weather changes. Barometric pressure changes lead to 20% more of ER visits for migraines.

sections.heading: Have Medication Readily Available
content: It’s important to take migraine medication like triptans or NSAIDs at the first sign of an attack or episode onset. One study found that taking these meds when your pain is mild leads to better outcomes. Having your prescriptions filled beforehand so you’re prepared can make all the difference in minimizing the extent of the episode.

It’s important to remember that comprehensive treatments go a long way for migraine and headache relief.  Along with medication, therapies like relaxation techniques, biofeedback, acupuncture, and staying active can help prevent and treat migraines.

I often recommend a combination of treatments for individualized care plans based on the preferences of each patient. Stress management is especially important, as research indicates cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) reduces migraine frequency and symptoms.

sections.heading: Follow Your Treatment Plan
content: Work with your doctor to create a tailored migraine treatment plan based on what works best for you and your preferences. It’s important to take preventive meds regularly, avoid triggers, track your headaches, and build in an acute treatment plan when your headaches happen. Consistency and resiliency building are key in finding the right therapies to reduce your migraine frequency. Don’t give up if a treatment doesn’t work. Persistence and determination pay off.

sections.heading: Watch What You Eat
content: Diet can play a major role in migraines, as certain foods and drinks are common triggers. The American Migraine Foundation recommends keeping a food diary and eliminating suspect foods one at a time to see if your migraines improve. Some potentially problematic foods include aged cheeses, processed meats, red wine, chocolate, nuts, caffeine, artificial sweeteners, and monosodium glutamate (MSG). I often recommend that patients consider a whole food plant-based diet, given more evidence emerging on the potential benefits of those for a variety of health conditions and your overall health.
Ensure you stay hydrated and limit alcohol intake as well. Getting enough magnesium, riboflavin (B2), coenzyme Q10, and other nutrients can be helpful for migraine prevention, according to research.

Work closely with your doctor or nutritionist to discover any dietary triggers, and optimize your diet for migraine management. One study found that a low-fat diet reduced migraine frequency and severity for those with obesity-related migraines.

Living with migraines presents challenges, but taking control of your treatment and triggers makes a big difference while working. Follow these evidence-based tips to start managing your migraines and keeping control of your productivity.
